February 11, 1996: Fiction
INTENSITY, by Dean Koontz. (Knopf, $25.) On a weekend visit to a Napa Valley
farm, a young woman contends with a serial killer.
THE HORSE WHISPERER, by Nicholas Evans. (Delacorte, $23.95.) A troubled
woman seeks solace for herself, her daughter and their horse from a wrangler in
Montana.
FIVE DAYS IN PARIS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) A chance encounter
between two Americans at the Ritz changes their lives forever.
CONTAGION, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $24.95.) A physician seeks to learn why a
deadly epidemic has struck a group of hospitals and clinics.
BEHIND THE LINES, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $23.95.) The Marine Corps
must cope with a bogus general in the Philippines during World War II.
THE WEB, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Bantam, $23.95.) On a research trip to a
Pacific island, Alex Delaware encounters a series of macabre events.
PRIMARY COLORS, by Anonymous. (Random House, $24.) The progress of a
certain Southern governor and his wife on their way to the White House.
SHOCK WAVE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) Dirk Pitt contends with
a ruthless man whose diamond-mining operations in Antarctica threaten human
life.
THE JUDGE, by Steve Martini. (Putnam, $23.95.) An attorney defends a judge he
doesn't like against murder and other charges.
THE CELESTINE PROPHECY, by James Redfield. (Warner, $17.95.) An ancient
manuscript, found in Peru, provides insights into achieving a fulfilling life.
HIDE & SEEK, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) A pop music star who
killed her first husband is on trial for murdering her second, a sports icon.
THE LOST WORLD, by Michael Crichton. (Knopf, $25.95.) Scientists visit a Costa
Rican jungle that is the breeding ground of dinosaurs; a sequel to "Jurassic Park."
THE MOOR'S LAST SIGH, by Salman Rushdie. (Pantheon, $25.) The rise,
decline and plunge to extinction of a wealthy Portuguese family in India.
ABSOLUTE POWER, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $22.95.) Political intrigue, sex
and murder in Washington's high circles.
THAT CAMDEN SUMMER, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $23.95.) In 1916, a
divorced woman, returning to her Maine hometown with her three daughters, finds
scorn, harassment and romance.
February 11, 1996
Non-Fiction
IT TAKES A VILLAGE, by Hillary Rodham Clinton. (Simon &Schuster, $20.) The
First Lady's quest for ways to help children create a better society.
RUSH LIMBAUGH IS A BIG FAT IDIOT, by Al Franken. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A
television comedian's comments on the current political scene.
HOW COULD YOU DO THAT?! by Laura Schlessinger. (HarperCollins,$22.) A
condemnation of self-indulgent morality, and ways to overcome it.
EMOTIONAL INTELLIGENCE, by Daniel Goleman. (Bantam, $23.95.) Factors
other than I.Q. that contribute to a successful and happy life.
THE ROAD AHEAD, by Bill Gates with Nathan Myhrvold and Peter Rinearson.
(Viking, $29.95.) What's ahead on the information highway; CD-ROM included.
CHARLES KURALT'S AMERICA, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $24.95.) From
Alaska to Florida: the most recent travels of the itinerant television reporter.
MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL, by John Berendt. (Random
House, $23.) The mysterious death of a young man in Savannah, Ga.
A SIMPLE PATH, by Mother Teresa. Compiled by Lucinda Vardey. (Ballantine,
$20.) The thoughts, experiences and beliefs of the Nobel Prize-winning nun.
LONGITUDE, by Dava Sobel. (Walker, $19.) The story of John Harrison, who
invented the chronometer.
MY POINT . . . AND I DO HAVE ONE, by Ellen DeGeneres. (Bantam,$19.95.)
Observations on life and the pursuit of happiness by the television star and
comedian.
SISTERS. Essays by Carol Saline. Photographs by Sharon J. Wohlmuth.
(Running Press, $27.50.) The relationships of 36 sets of sisters.
TIME PRESENT, TIME PAST, by Bill Bradley. (Knopf, $26.) The Senator from
New Jersey reflects on his life and on what he believes lies ahead for this country.
MISS AMERICA, by Howard Stern. (Regan Books, $27.50.) Anecdotes and
fulminations from the radio talk show host.
DAVID BRINKLEY, by David Brinkley. (Knopf, $25.) From a boyhood in North
Carolina through five decades as a television newscaster: a memoir.
AMAZING GRACE, by Jonathan Kozol. (Crown, $23.) Life as experienced by
children in the South Bronx.
ALL I KNOW ABOUT ANIMAL BEHAVIOR I LEARNED IN LOEHMANN'S
